title: The effect of free childcare on maternal labour supply and child development
abstractText:
The UK government spends billions of pounds a year to ensure that all 3 and 4 year olds have access to childcare and early education. Yet there is surprisingly little evidence on the causal impact of this intervention.

This project will provide the most comprehensive causal analysis of the effects of free childcare provision on maternal employment and child development using UK data.  The project team will look at different instances of variation in the availability of free childcare for pre-school children in England. In particular, they will study:

  • the provision of free part-time childcare to the most disadvantaged children which characterised the UK policies of the 1990s
  • the provision of universal entitlement to free part-time childcare introduced in the early 2000s
  • date-of-birth discontinuities in entitlement to part-time pre-school care and full-time school education.

The project will consider a wide range of outcomes including maternal employment, hours of work, working patterns, search behaviour and participation in further education, and - for the child - measures of educational attainment at various ages and socio-emotional development. Results will relate to different time-periods, policy settings and groups of families and therefore will inform on the effectiveness of various policy parameters.
